etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Cooper (c1517–1594), theologian and bishop of Winchester. As adjective from post-classical Latin semitertianus, adjective

definitions: Of a fever, especially malaria: having characteristics of both quotidian and tertian fevers; specifically characterized by paroxysms of fever and chills which recur every other day, but with little remission of fever on the intervening day.

notes.text: This pattern of fever is now thought to be characteristic of falciparum malaria.

definitions: Semitertian fever; an instance of this.
